climbs.name: You Can Cry If You Want To

content.description: Start standing matched at a big sidepull/undercling and climb straight up with good crimps and slippery feet to a monster jug at the lip.
content.location: The last line on the north end of the Hall of the Mountain Queens

content.description: After making the mantle move reach up to the small left facing crimp, but now continue more or less straight up avoiding the horizontal rail rightwards.
Start on very thin crimps and climb up and slightly right past better crimps and a good horizontal crack to the juggy lip.
content.location: Just left of You Can Cry If You Want To, on the right side of the Mountain Queens wall

content.description: Start on the two conspicuous large crimps. Make a tricky move up using a tiny crimp to stand on the starting holds. Then move right slightly, using a better diagonal hold to walk the feet up and grab the top. Harder variation (v3/4?) heads up and slightly left from the two big crimps using horrendous tiny feet and NOT the crack of head butt. Easier variation continues further right from the diagonal crimp to the horizontal crack of There Is No Party (Right)
content.location: Start near the middle of the Hall of the Mountain Queens on the two conspicuous large crimps.

content.description:
Located between

Head Butt

and

There is no Party Left (variation)

this problem takes a direct line up the slab.

Start with a high step up the make a couple of committing moves on poor feed to reach better holds below the lip.    Finish direct.
From the normal route before reaching the good left facing flake move up leftwards via poor crimps and terrible feet.

Using small feet and all sorts of awkward motion, climb up to and up the ramp. Could be done either using the ramp for hands with feet below, or ramp for feet with hands above, or both. A bit contrived as it comes very close to Head Butt at the top and it is hard to avoid bailing out right to the better holds of that problem.
content.location: The obvious right slanting ramp on the left end of the Hall of the Mountain Queens

content.description:
Sit start with right hand up on a sloper.   Move up right along the edge before making tricky moves up to gain the arete.

Take care with the rock at your back.
content.protection: Pads and spotters (for the rock at your back)

content.description:
Climb directly up the slab via small but positive holds.

A great intro to the slab!
content.location: A few feet right of the left end

content.description: On the Hall of the Mountain Queen slab boulder, this committing V1 requires precise footwork to gain the security of the seamy jugs halfway up. A must do problem!
content.protection: Mostly flat landing, two pads would be recommended as there is a small rock and tree stump at the base of the climb. Trustworthy spotter might make you feel good too!
content.location:
Hall of the Mtn. Queens slab is a North face on a long, highish boulder creating one wall of the 'hall'.

A couple feet right of the obvious right trending ramp, the problem starts on thin crimps and thinnner feet, moving up to a sweet little finger crack then up to some horizontals. Look for the Thank God jug out left and downclimb the arete on the far left side of the boulder (as you face the climb) or walk down back and jump to adjacent ledge (not recommended).

content.description: Sit start with right hand on a good in-cut crimp.   Make a hard pull to get standing on the input crimp then move easily up the arete to finish.
Sit start where possible then move up and rightwards using what ever holds you can before possible to move up and over as the lip steepens.
